learning_outcomes.description: Assess historiographical evidence from primary sources regarding the nature and status of rights and freedoms, including the relationship between rights, freedoms, and other principles of law
Position primary sources in relation to the dominant intellectual traditions of rights and freedoms
Use primary source evidence to build arguments
Demonstrate scholarly analytical and reasoning skills regarding the relationship between primary sources and debates regarding rights and freedoms
Demonstrate ability to communicate clearly and persuasively about rights and freedoms in written and spoken form

assessments.task_description:
Students will be assessed on their participation in class. Grades are awarded based on the ability to provide convincing interpretations of set primary sources by presenting evidence drawn from the sources. No marks are awarded for general reflections that don't relate to the texts, unless these are specifically asked for in class. Additionally, no marks are awarded merely for seminar attendance, but 5 marks will be deducted from the overall participation grade for each seminar missed without cause.


This assessment task evaluates students’ abilities, skills and knowledge without the aid of Artificial Intelligence (AI). Students are advised that the use of AI technologies to develop responses is strictly prohibited and may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.

assessments.task_description:
Students are required to submit a 2,000 word research essay based on a selected essay question. 

 

This assessment task evaluates students’ abilities, skills and knowledge without the aid of Artificial Intelligence (AI). Students are advised that the use of AI technologies to develop responses is strictly prohibited and may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
Students are required to submit a brief written analysis of the weekly set texts. This analysis must conform to the model laid out under the ‘Assessment’ tab on Blackboard. It is possible to be awarded a maximum of 10 marks per summary, and there are 12 classes in which a summary is due (every week except week 1). As this assessment item is scored out of 100, the result is that the 10-best grades are chosen, and the two-worst excluded. This does not mean a student can only submit 10 summaries – 5 marks are deducted per missing summary. 

This assessment task evaluates students’ abilities, skills and knowledge without the aid of Artificial Intelligence (AI). Students are advised that the use of AI technologies to develop responses is strictly prohibited and may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
Length: approx. 1,500 words

Students will be required to select a contemporary statement regarding rights and freedoms from a list of choices, and critically analyse this statement in terms of the intellectual traditions studied in this course.

 

This assessment task evaluates students’ abilities, skills and knowledge without the aid of Artificial Intelligence (AI). Students are advised that the use of AI technologies to develop responses is strictly prohibited and may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.
